name.text: 1.4.2.1 Multiplication and division of algebraic fractions

questiontext.text:
Multiplication and division of algebraic fractions

To multiply together two fractions (numerical or algebraic) we multiply their numerators together and then multiply their denominators together. That is

Key Point

Multiplication

\[ \dfrac{a}{b} \times \dfrac{c}{d} = \dfrac{ac}{bd} \]


Any factors common to both numerator and denominator can be cancelled. This cancellation can be performed before or after the multiplication.

To divide one fraction by another (numerical or algebraic) we invert the second fraction and then multiply.

Key Point

Division of fractions

\[ \dfrac{a}{b} \div \dfrac{c}{d} = \dfrac{a}{b} \times \dfrac{d}{c} = \dfrac{ad}{bc} \quad b\neq 0, \, c\neq0, \, d\neq 0 \]


Example

Simplify:

  1. \(\dfrac{2a}{c} \times \dfrac{4}{c}\)
  2. \(\dfrac{2a}{c} \times \dfrac{c}{4}\)
  3. \(\dfrac{2a}{c} \div \dfrac{4}{c}\)

Solution

  1. \(\dfrac{2a}{c} \times \dfrac{4}{c} = \dfrac{8a}{c^2}\)
  2. \(\dfrac{2a}{c} \times \dfrac{c}{4} = \dfrac{2ac}{4c} = \dfrac{2a}{4}= \dfrac{a}{2}\)

  3. Division is performed by inverting the second fraction and then multiplying.

    \(\dfrac{2a}{c} \div \dfrac{4}{c} = \dfrac{2a}{c} \times \dfrac{c}{4}= \dfrac{a}{2}\)

Example

Simplify:

  1. \(\dfrac{1}{5x} \times 3x\)
  2. \(\dfrac{1}{x} \times x\)

Solution

  1. Note that \(3x = \dfrac{3x}{1}.\)

    Then \(\dfrac{1}{5x} \times 3x = \dfrac{1}{5x} \times \dfrac{3x}{1} = \dfrac{3x}{5x}= \dfrac{3}{5}.\)

  2. \(x\) can be written as \( \dfrac{x}{1}.\)

    Then \(\dfrac{1}{x} \times x = \dfrac{1}{x} \times \dfrac{x}{1}= \dfrac{x}{x} = 1.\)
